Award.AwardTitle: Embedded and Immersed Surfaces in Three-Dimensional Topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The guiding question in three-dimensional topology is the classification problem for three-dimensional manifolds - to construct a list in which every homeomorphism type appears exactly once. The PI will both address this question and explore applications of the resulting methods to the topology of large data sets in three components: First, the PI will expand and refine techniques developed recently by Minsky, Namazi, Souto and others to related hyperbolic geometry to topology via Teichmuller theory. Second, the PI will generalize these techniques to answer questions about finite covers of three-dimensional manifolds suggested by the recent proof of the Virtual Haken Conjecture. Third, the PI will explore applications of these topological techniques to data analysis in order to develop and refine new algorithms that will be useful to scientists in a broad range of fields.

A 3-dimensional manifold is a topological space that models the 3-dimensional universe in which we live. Heegaard splittings are topological structures that allow one to see such a space as a pair of simple pieces that have been combined in a possibly complicated manner. While Heegaard splittings have been studied for over a century, our knowledge of Heegaard splittings has only in the last two decades matured to the point where they can be thoroughly understood. They are now an integral part of understanding geometric structures on 3-manifolds and knots. Moreover, recent developments have demonstrated that techniques (particularly one called thin position) used in the abstract study of Heegaard splittings can be adapted to work on certain problems in applied mathematics, particularly the analysis of large data sets. The research funded by this grant will develop both the abstract and the applied aspects of this field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Three-Dimensional Topology is the area of mathematics that studies sets having a structure on them called a topology that is locally modeled on three-dimensional space.  If this topoology satisfies certain consistency conditions, the topological spaces are call three-manifolds. The major problem of three-manifold topology is to understand completely the structure of three-manioflds and provide a classification, i.e., a listing of all three-manifolds so that given any three-manifold there is a way to determine exactly where it is located on the list. The research from this project is a study of surfaces (two-dimensional manifolds) contained in the three-manifold and having various properties that indicates they are essential to the structure of the three-manifold. As this research developed it evolved into a deeper study of triangulations, ways in which all three-manifolds can be decomposed/constructed and the classes of minimal surfaces in these manifolds, which we call normal and almost normal surfaces. Significant advances were made toward understanding how to effectively and efficiently transfer from one triangulation of a 3-manifold to another  and to determine the minimal triangulations of a number of infinite families of three-manifolds. These are the first infinite families where the minimal triangulations have been determined. Financial support was provided for a graduate student who completed their doctoral degree during the time of this project. In addition the project supported variouss young researchers in three-dimensional to make contact with collaborators and advance their research into this area of mathematics.  The outcome has been a number of research articles and several young mathematics researchers attracted to related studies of three-manifolds.
